17.title: Quotas
17.content:
Quotas


Introduction to quotas


First Come, First Served Quotas


In-depth view of data tables


Licensed quotas


Quota user needs


Quota business rules




A quota is used to control quantities of particular goods being imported.

Introduction to quotas

A quota is used as a means of controlling the flow of goods into a country in order to create a balance between:


the needs of consumers or manufacturing industries that would use the item as a component or ingredient in producing something else in the importing countries and
domestic producers of the good, whose livelihood depends on producing and selling a product to domestic customers at full market price.

For example, tomatoes are imported into the European Union from Mediterranean countries and other places with temperate climates in order to satiate the needs of European citizens for tomatoes and sauces containing tomatoes. In Southern Europe, there are tomato growers for whom the overseas suppliers are rivals that threaten their livelihood.
In the UK, sheep farmers depend on selling their goods to a UK market hungry for lamb and lamb products; but there is not enough lamb in the UK to satisfy our needs, hence the need to import lamb from New Zealand and other countries.
This is a fine balance that needs to be managed carefully in order to support the needs of the two contrasting needs: the need for the nation to consume and need for domestic suppliers to make a living.
This is where quotas come in.


Get to know Peter Ungphakorn


Peter Ungphakorn was a senior information officer with the WTO Secretariat until 2015.
Since then he has moved into journalism, focusing mainly on international trade rules, agreements and institutions and fortunately making his knowledge available to the public via his Trade Beta Blog.
This blog contains very good, simple explainers (for seven and a half year-olds) on a number of topics, including quotas.




Read above about Tariff Rate Quotas (TRQs) (less so quantitative restrictions)
See also his blog on Meursing tables which simplifies an incredibly complex subject.

What is a quota?


A quota allows a certain volume of goods to be imported into a country at a reduced duty rate.
Once that volume has been imported, then the quota is considered to be exhausted and is no longer available to draw down against.
At that point, all importers will be forced to import the goods at the full (or less preferential duty rate).


What properties does a quota have?


Returning to the lamb quota on the previous screen, clicking on the term “092016” shows more detail of the quota.
“092016” is the quota order number. If any trader wants to take advantage of the preferential duties associated with a quota, then they need to quote that 6-digit quota order number on their import declaration. A quota1 has properties such as those shown here
These properties are described on the following pages


Defining quotas
There are multiple ways of defining and grouping quotas, all of which will be relevant to the delivery of the next iteration of the Tariff Application:


Administration mechanism:


First come first served 
Licensed

Legislative mechanism:


WTO quota
ATQ
preferential quota as part of an FTA 
safeguard quota

Origin quota: 


Yes
No


If you were to draw a Venn-style diagram of how these slices fit together, it would look a bit like this:

Preferential vs Non-Preferential quotas
Preferential quotas


The term preferential means that a single country or bloc is afforded treatment that provides better market access / lower duties than other countries.
In practical terms, preferential tariff duties and quotas are almost always made available via (Free) Trade Agreements. The quota is agreed as part of the bilateral negotiation between the two parties that provides each with mutual benefits.
Preferential quotas are always applied at a specific country or small group of countries.
Within the EU, there are a very small number of quotas which are applied to multiple countries (e.g. a wine quota available for imports from multiple W. Balkan countries), but most are aimed explicitly at one country or bloc.
Among the few exceptions, Greenland benefits from preferential quotas on seafoods outside of a formal Trade Agreement

Non-Preferential quotas


Non-preferential quotas are aimed at maintaining the balance of trade flows on critical goods by opening up a specific volume of market access to all overseas nations – in most cases, the non-preferential quotas are assigned to ERGA OMNES1 (the country group that includes all countries).
There are very few officially non-preferential quotas that have been opened up to specific countries only, where there is a need to maintain global trade flows with a less blunt instrument than a global non-preferential quota applied to the entire world, especially where there are trade titans in a particular commodity
Lamb is again a great example of this – there is a non-preferential quota for Erga Omnes (small volume) and much larger non-prefs for specific countries like Chile, Australia and New Zealand – each of which is a dominant player in the lamb trade.

Ways of administering quotas
There are two methods of administering a quota:
First Come First Served quotas


These are by far the most common of the two types of quota.
As the name suggests, a FCFS quota involves making a pot available to traders: whoever claims against that pot first gets to take advantage of the reduced rate.
If you’re not quick enough, you miss the opportunity and pay the non-preferential rate.

Licensed quotas


The purpose of a licensed quota is the same as a FCFS quota: to protect the fine balance of trade flows, however the mechanism for applying for usage is very different.
For each quota, periods of the year are opened up for importers to apply for licenses from the Rural Payments Agency (RPA) - a division of Defra.
During this period, the RPA accepts these license requests and issues licenses according to the specific rules of the quota
In the EU tariff, all licensed quotas’ 6-digit quota order numbers begin with “094”.

Origin quotas
Some quotas identify as Origin Quotas (about 25%)
Origin quotas allow for specific quantities of some products to receive preferential tariff treatment if the products meet certain conditions, for example a proof of origin can be provided to prove that the goods do in fact come from the specific country.
Origin quotas are always preferential in nature.
For a good example of an origin quota, please see the cat & dog food quota in place with Canada, where a proof of origin certificate is explicitly required.

The reason why this is important is that a quota’s origin status is displayed on the reference documents that accompany a trade agreements (as a schedule to the primary SI).
WTO quotas


The UK declares a tariff “schedule of concessions” to the WTO which is made up of multiple elements – what interests us most here is:
the tariff schedule
the schedules for tariff quotas on agricultural and non-agricultural products
The quota schedules list the concessions that we will make to overseas nations to provide greater market access to our market than would have been afforded by adopting the MFN rate alone.
In most cases, WTO quotas are assigned to the whole world (ERGA OMNES), but in certain cases (e.g. with lamb), the quota concessions are made available to individual countries which major in a certain trade (e.g. New Zealand for lamb).
Almost all WTO quotas are agricultural goods (this also applies to the other kinds of quota).


Autonomous quotas (ATQs)


Autonomous quotas are represented in the tariff as simple “Non-preferential quotas”. These are particularly applicable within the fishing industry. There is contention within the fishing industry between the catching sector and the food and processing sector.
For highly consumed goods, such as cod, pollock and prawns, the UK / EU catching industry cannot catch sufficient product to satisfy the needs of the home and international market. Therefore the processing industry needs access to low or zero duty for such products, while the catching industry needs protection by retaining at least some maximum import threshold above which normal tariff duties apply.
The autonomous tariff rate quota (ATQ) facilitates this compromise – a quantity of goods can be imported into the EU at zero or low rate, until exhausted, at which point the duty reverts to the third country rate
ATQs are set on a three year cycle: the ATQ duty rate cannot be changed in the course of that 3 year cycle, however the starting balance for each year can be assessed at the start of each year.
For fisheries ATQs, there is an additional point of interest, that, if 80% or more of the quota has been exhausted by the end of September in any given year, then the balance of the quota is increased by 20%
Autonomous Quotas so called, as the EU unilaterally decides to open a quota – there is no requirement for recourse to WTO approval to open an ATQ.
It is anticipated that the ATQs will continue to operate post-Brexit as they are favoured within the Defra ministry and offer a compromise to the different parts of the industry.

What products are covered by quotas?

Identifying quota types


Unfortunately, it is not a simple matter to take a quota order number and determine what kind of quota is being used. In the EU Tariff:


All current EU quota order numbers begin with 09 without exception
“094” means licensed quota
Autonomous agriculture quotas begin 0977
Autonomous fisheries quotas begin 0987

Apart from that, there are few obvious rules that define the EU’s use of quotas.
The system for identifying quotas in the UK tariff will be determined in the course of 2020.

Managing quota order numbers


DIT must take the lead in managing quota order numbers – this process has been introduced but not properly observed.
It needs to be a consultative process between DIT, HMRC and Defra to avoid errors and confusion, e.g. reusing existing quota order numbers
How quotas get set up is dependent on what they have been used for previously – we have inadvertently selected quota order numbers that were a cross section of closed and open quota order numbers, which have caused management challenges in previous migrations.
As of March 26th, the likelihood is that quota order numbers in the UK will be using ”08” as their first two digits to differentiate from the EU, with specific challenges around the dual Tariff in Northern Ireland being the primary cause. This remains to be agreed and properly analysed however.

Quotas in reference documents



Above is a sample of the quota section of a reference document – it lists the quotas that are applicable to a given country or trading bloc (here is a mocked-up reference document for the ESA1 trading bloc).
The three highlighted data elements (with largely made up data for illustration purposes only), are data fields over and above what the Taric requires: these are not data that is needed by the HMRC systems, but is of benefit to creating reference documents.
In TAPv1, the reference document creation service had been created as a totally separate application (using Python / Django), whereas in round 2, it needs to be integrated.
Please see the training document on reference documents for more information

First Come, First Served Quotas

First Come, First Served quotas are far more prevalent than licensed quotas on the Tariff database.
As the name suggests this favours those traders that apply for the quota first
Then, once the initial volume assigned to the quota has been fully depleted, the quota is deemed to be exhausted and is no longer available to draw down against. Once depleted, the trader’s import then falls back on the next best import duty, which may be a tariff preference, but it more likely just the MFN duty.
There is an important difference in the way in which FCFS are managed compared to licensed quotas:
FCFS quotas pass through the HMRC systems that are of greatest interest to the DIT Tariff Application (CHIEF and CDS)
Licensed quotas do not touch HMRC systems: instead they are handled essentially off-system via the RPA (see following slides)
The way in which the DIT application handles the different types of quotas is very different, as will be discussed.

First Come First Served (FCFS) quotas: in the EU and with CHIEF
This diagram shows the data flows of traders making declarations on CHIEF against the EU’s quota allocation system for first come, first served quotas. At the time of writing (March 2020), 100% of the UK’s FCFS quota-related trade goes via this route (i.e. no involvement from CDS).

First Come First Served (FCFS) quotas: in the EU still and with CDS
The migration of CHIEF to CDS had been planned some time before the referendum, as CHIEF is legacy software that, despite being highly reliable, is difficult to maintain and extend to cater for new requirements (such as full adherence to the UCC -  Union Customs Code). This diagram is an extension of the previous diagram while CHIEF is excluded from this diagram (to save complexity), it will still be in place for some time anyway – and thanks to the NI Protocol, probably for another 2 years at least. In reality, this planned architecture will not be available to GB traders for the foreseeable future, thanks to the required pivot to support NI.

NI Protocol has changed the approach to CDS migration and this impacts quotas
The NI Protocol requires (over-simplified):


all goods imported into Northern Ireland to be subject to EU regulatory controls in full
all goods considered to be at risk of entering the EU via the NI / ROI boundary to be subject to EU import duties
while those goods that are not at risk are subject to GB duties

This requires 2 tariffs to be present to work out the applicable duties based on the circumstances of the individual trade. This is too complex to do in CHIEF and a huge overhead to do in two systems concurrently anyway.
Therefore CDS is now designated solely for NI traders (plus the 10 traders that have already been migrated), whereas all other (GB) traders will remain on CHIEF until a future date (to be specified).
The impact on quotas is that, by extension, imports to NI of at risk goods may still claim on EU quotas, and these requests will continue to need to be allocated via the EU Quota 2 system while UK quotas will be allocated by the new CDS Quota Allocation Module (QAM). There is a strong possibility for confusion for traders if the UK continues to share the same quota order numbers as the EU.
Architecture to support NI post Transition Period
Key points to note in this diagram – CDS will have two tariff modules, one served by the EU to support NI regulatory controls and at risk duties, the other to support GB trade and NI not at risk trade. In theory (to be negotiated and unlikely to be deliverable by Jan 21), NI at risk goods will be able to take advantage of EU quotas, and therefore be allocated via Quota 2, not QAM. CHIEF GB declarations will send quota requests to QAM for allocation.

The Taric and FCFS quotas
The data objects that are utilised for FCFS are vastly more numerous than those used for licensed quotas
Licensed quotas essentially use just measures not any of the other quota related tables. That is because all the other tables are set up uniquely to manage the set up and decrementing of quota balances.

The timespans of a FCFS quota


There are no limits on the periods that quotas can span, but there are commonalities, which these pages aim to share.
There are no quotas that are essentially one-offs – a quota is a permanent instrument to balance trade, not a one-time hit. The only slight deviation from this concerns the quotas that have been put in place to provide checks and balances on the import of steel goods (Steel safeguards), which evolve annually: this is just because the instrument is immature, not because it is a one-off.
The following types of quota periodicity can be found in the tariff:


Annual full year quota running from Jan 1st to December 31st and repeating every year
Annual full year quota running from another start date (e.g. July 1st to June 30th) and repeating every year
Part year quota running from any date to any other date (e.g. Feb 14th to May 31st) and repeating between the same dates every year
Quarterly quota running from Jan 1st to December 31st and repeating on that pattern every year
Quarterly quota running from another start date but lasting a full 12 months and repeating on that pattern every year
Part year quota split into monthly sections and repeating every year

These periods are enshrined in the legislation that engenders them – there is no deviation on the start and end dates of the periods (though watch out for leap years)

Timespans in graphical format

Impact of European growing seasons

There are more factors at play in determining quota volumes and periods than growing seasons (or marketing periods as they are called), but time of year is important for the EU, especially for Mediterranean countries.
In time, seasonality may be of less importance to the UK, as our climate does not (yet) suit the industrial levels of production seen in Southern Europe.
Quota staging


The ultimate goal of a trade agreement is often to get to a place where there is a 0% import duty on goods being imported
But, if that goal were to be reached immediately, the toxic shock to domestic producers would be potentially crippling, as  internal markets are swept away in one fell swoop by cheap and abundant imports.
Therefore the idea of staging has been adopted to allow domestic businesses to adjust to the new reality over time.
Staging periods equate to the period over which a trade agreement reaches it ultimate goal:


for tariff preferences, this is usually finite. For example, an agreement may include the goal to reduce an import duty from 10% (the pre-agreement MFN) to 0% over 4 years, reducing by 2.5% per year. After 4 years, the duty remains at 0% for as long as the agreement remains in place
for staging in quotas, there is no finite end goal, just an increase in the volume of goods made available to the quota. For example at the start of a trade agreement, a quota may permit the import of 100,000 KGM of goods at a reduced rate. The agreement states that an additional 10,000 KGM are permitted per year. I have not seen a ceiling placed on this (e.g. an extra 10,000 KGM a year until it reached 200,000 KGM), but that does not mean it does not happen. The relaxation always takes place against the quota volume, not against the in-quota duties.

Staging often appears in quotas created as part of a Trade Agreement, but never in WTO quotas or ATQs

Safeguard quotas


Since 2018, the EU has imposed quotas as part of its Steel Safeguards programme. Since 2017, USA has imposed swingeing import duties on steel and related goods coming into the country in order to protect its own industry from collapse
This led to a huge increase in the quantities of such goods coming into the European Union, as manufacturers (usually in the Far East), who previously had easy pickings in USA, now had to seek alternative markets.
The knock-on impact was felt in EU domestic steel suppliers, hence the imposition of steel safeguards by the EU.
Safeguards had been extremely rare in the EU until 2018 and the use of quotas to support them had never been seen. Now they are part of the EU’s defence armoury and will be adopted largely like-for-like by the UK after the end of the implementation period.
The safeguard works like this:


a punitive duty of 25% import duty (type 696 – Additional duties (safeguard)) is applied to multiple steel products grouped in 28 categories. The duty is applied to c. 100 countries
then individual quotas are overlaid to remove the duties for certain countries up to a given volume – different quotas are set up for each of the 28 groups (with many country exclusions), some of the quotas being annual and some of the quotas being quarterly

This function is documented in detail elsewhere – warning: it is hugely complex and warrants very detailed attention.
Knowing about the concepts behind quotas before digging into the safeguards will prepare you for the complexity.

Introductory periods


There are very many cases where an annual cadence is set up for a quota with an introductory period at the start that allows the quota to, for example, coincide with the Day One live implementation of a trade agreement, but to still allow the cadence to follow a marketing period.
This ‘introductory period’ will be critical also in the migration of quotas from the EU to the UK – if the implementation period ends on December 31st 2020, then there will be many quotas which will naturally start in the UK tariff on 1st January 2021, 


This is the mode (annual quotas that run for a calendar year).
But, any quota that does not commence on Jan 1st for its annual cadence will potentially require an introductory period
for example, an annual quota that starts on July 1st will require a 6-month introductory period
the steel safeguard quotas that typically run in quarters from July 1st to June 30th will require two introductory periods of three months each
but a quotas which runs from Valentine’s day to the end of June will not

The quota definition table


The quota definition table is the table which defines the cadence of the quota and the volume of the goods that can be imported at reduced rates during each period.
The definition table does not contain any information about:


the commodity codes that are impacted
the geographical areas from which goods can be imported
the in quota duties that apply

There are a lot of tables that impact quotas, but the four below do the bulk of the work – the division of labour is noted
You may also hear quota definition referred to as quota account by HMRC.”

      Criticality


As described above, the critical state determines if a trader needs to pay securities when utilising the quota.
The purpose of the requirement to collect securities is to


a) attempt to provide some sort of level playing field for traders as a quota reaches exhaustion
b) try to reduce returns towards the end of a definition’s active life span – managing returns is a hassle and if a trader has paid a security, the are less likely to be blasé with unused quota volume.

It is up to DIT to set the critical state of a quota definition, as we set all the properties of a quota definition period before it has begun, including critical state.
The rules of thumb are:
a new quota should be set to critical for three years so that there is an opportunity to study trade flows to determine if the volumes are correct
setting critical to ‘Y’ for this period ensures that the trade flow is more reflective of actual trade, dispensing with traders that declare a need for quota volume, but then do not use it.
BUT at the same time, for HMRC to take securities is a major overhead and they prefer not to in all cases.
So, during the 3 non-Brexits to date, the critical state for all quota definition periods has been set to N initially:


in order to reduce workload for HMRC
because most trade flows were fairly well known through UK;s membership of the EU
we were not introducing many genuinely new quotas (though the maxim was applied to all)

HMRC will need to be consulted in the lead-up to the implementation period on what they want to do with criticality: it is their domain, but our responsibility to set the initial state. This will be especially vital if we kick off any brand new trade deals with new overseas trading partners on Day One, which is remotely possible.

Managing geography

A FCFS quota only works when the full set of quota tables and measure tables are all set up and synchronised. It’s important to understand a few points around the geography of these two entities in order to create the right data.
* geography has to be set correctly against both the measure and the quota order number
* while the measures table has a 1-2-1 relationship with geographical areas, the quota order number table can relate to multiple origins via the many-to-many linking table “quota order number origins”.
*Geographical areas – concepts *
Assigning quotas to countries


A quota can be assigned either to an individual country or to a group of countries
As described on the previous page, it may also be assigned to multiple (single) countries as well; theoretically, there is no reason why the quota cannot be assigned to multiple country groups simultaneously, though this has never happened.
There are currently (in the EU tariff) several quotas that are assigned to multiple (single) countries, but these will not carry over into the UK tariff (needs to be re-checked).


For example, quota order number 091530 is assigned to import of wines from the Western Balkan states of Albania, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Kosovo, North Macedonia, Montenegro and Serbia.
While the UK will aim to engineer trade agreements with all 6 of these prior to the end of the implementation period, the quotas will be split into individual quotas per country.

The aim must be to still permit assignment of quotas to multiple countries however, as the model permits it.
For each assignment of geographical area to quota order number, the following is required:


a record in the measures table, linking geographical_area_id and ordernumber.
a record in the quota_order_number_origins table, linking geographical_area_id and quota_order_number_id.


Excluding countries from quotas


When a quota is assigned to a country group, it is possible and very common to exclude countries from that group, such that the quota does not apply to that country. Examples of this are:


quotas that apply on food and drink that apply to Central America, but from which Panama is excluded
almost all of the steel safeguard quotas feature multiple exclusions.

Obviously, the excluded country may be a member of the country group that’s assigned to the quota.
For each exclusion of a country from a quota associated to a country group, the following is required:


a record in the quota order number origin exclusions table, linking the origin and the excluded geographical area.
a record in the measure_excluded_geographical_areas table, linking the origin and the excluded geographical area.

Strategies for managing origins and exclusions


Quota order number origins have start dates and end dates
Quota order number origins do not have start dates and end dates
If you want to alter the quota order number origin exclusions for a quota, and you don’t want it to happen immediately, you cannot just add the exclusion to the origin: it will take effect immediately, which is almost certainly not the requirement.
As case in point is the steel safeguards:


each year to date, the origin exclusions have been tweaked as the EU has discovered more about world trade flows and the impact of both the US and EU safeguards on that flow
the EU has not been able to just remove and add exclusions

There are two options:


either end the origin and start another origin
or end the quota order number and start another quota order number with a new origin

The EU chooses the latter option: terminating the quota order number and replacing with another one starting the next day with a new origin.


in TAP1, we followed this route: the alternative route may also be followed.


Quota exception periods and events



Linked to the definition tables are 8 additional tables:


2 of these, the period tables are useful – these are discussed in the relevant documents (blocking and suspending quotas)
The other 6 are of no interest to DIT in terms of managing the UK tariff – these are reflections of the operational state of EU quotas. As DIT has no interest in the operationalisation of the quotas, we will not need to worry about them.

If there is a requirement to continue to support the EU tariff, then all data tables should be loaded, including the events tables.
The tables are extremely simple nonetheless, should they be required.
There is an additional entity in the XSD, the quota.closed.and.transferred.event which is historical

      Licensed quota process – by example (garlic)


Possible garlic traders are grouped into two groups:


new importers – 30% of quota licenses are available for new importers
traditional importers – 70% of quota licenses are available for traditional importers (those who can prove they have imported garlic frequently over the last x years)

All declarants must register with the RPA (Rural Payments Agency)
Applications must be submitted using an import licence application form (AGRIM), downloadable from gov.uk
Quota applications may be made at certain specific periods in the year (for garlic, applications must be received during the first seven calendar days of April, July, October and January), and must be accompanied by securities and proof of trade
Licenses are issued within a given date window, and may be used then in a short fixedperiod only from the point of issue
Most importantly for us, all we need to set up is the relationship between thecommodity, the measure type, the time period, the in-quota duty rate and the origin– there is no concept of number of licenses / import volumes to be concernedabout in DIT.

TAP 1 – Approach to licensed quotas


The approach to building quotas in the first version of the Tariff Application was to not use any of the tables outside of the blue marquee on the previous screen for building licensed quotas.
The reason for this was to avoid any data for licensed quotas being sent to the HMRC systems that would cause compatibility issues on arrival. Therefore, that project only used the measures table for licensed quotas
It may be considered as useful to use at least the quota_order_number table to capture quota order numbers in the 2nd iteration if this helps certain functions in the new application, such as the quota search function, then it may be advisable to utilise this table
The approach needs to be decided by the new team
The database that you will receive on arrival will contain no reference to licensed quotas at all in any tables other than the measures table.

QD7

The validity period of the quota definition must be   spanned by one of the validity periods of the referenced quota order number.

Required – medium priority   Just don’t end date quota order numbers – and only use   them once; will save a lot of time



Relation with monetary unit



QD8

The validity period of the monetary unit code must span   the validity period of the quota definition.

Not required   We will only be using pound sterling


QD9

The monetary unit code must always be the Euro ISO code   (or Ecu for quota defined prior to the Euro Definition).

Not required   We will only be using pound sterling



Relation with measurement unit



QD10

The validity period of the measurement unit code must span   the validity period of the quota definition.

Required – low priority   Just do not terminate the measurement units



Relation with measurement unit qualifier



QD11

The validity period of the measurement unit qualifier code   must span the validity period of the quota definition.

Required – low priority   Just do not terminate the measurement qualifier units



Relation with quota event



QD12

If quota events exist for a quota definition, the start   date of the quota definition cannot be brought forward.

Not required   We do not deal in quota events – preserve of CDS


QD13

If quota events exist for a quota definition, the start   date can only be postponed up to the date of the first quota event.

Not required   We do not deal in quota events – preserve of CDS


QD14

If quota events exist for a quota definition, the end date   of the quota definition can be postponed.

Not required   We do not deal in quota events – preserve of CDS


QD15

If quota events exist for a quota definition, the end date   can only be brought forward up to the date of the last quota event on that   quota definition.

Not required   We do not deal in quota events – preserve of CDS



Quota Association



QA1

The association between two quota definitions must be   unique.

Required – high priority   Associations are made between a definition of a main   (parent) quota and a definition of a sub (child) quota. There may not be more   than one association connecting the same two definitions.


QA2

The sub-quota’s validity period must be entirely enclosed   within the validity period of the main quota

Required – high priority   Associations are made between a definition of a main   (parent) quota and a definition of a sub (child) quota. There may not be more   than one association connecting the same two definitions.


QA3

When converted to the measurement unit of the main quota,   the volume of a sub-quota must always be lower than or equal to the volume of   the main quota.

Required – medium priority   In fact, we should never permit there to be different   units on the main and sub quotas – it becomes impossible to manage


QA4

Whenever a sub-quota receives a coefficient, this has to   be a strictly positive decimal number. When it is not specified a value of 1   is always assumed

Required – high priority   Ignore the 2nd clause here – we must always be explicit   in specifying the coefficient for all associations


QA5

Whenever a sub-quota is defined with the ‘equivalent’   type, it must have the same volume as the ones associated with the parent   quota. Moreover it must be defined with a coefficient not equal to 1

Required – high priority   As per description


QA6

Sub-quotas associated with the same main quota must have   the same relation type

Required – high priority   As per description – there is often, but not always,   more than one association of a main quota to sub quotas – they must be of the   same type



Quota Blocking Period



QBP1

The quota definition SID must exist.

Required – medium priority   Will be picked from a dropdown


QBP2

The start date of the quota blocking period must be later   than or equal to the start date of the quota validity period.

Required – high priority   This actually means the quota definition validity   period, not the quota order number – quite unclear. They also omit to say   that the end date of the blocking period must be no later than the end date   of the definition


QBP3

The end date of the quota blocking period must be later   than the start date of the quota blocking period.

Required – high priority   As per description



Quota Suspension Period



QSP1

The quota definition SID must exist.

Required – medium priority   Will be picked from a dropdown


QSP2

The validity period of the quota must span the quota   suspension period.

Required – high priority   This actually means the quota definition validity   period, not the quota order number – quite unclear. But a better, more   generic description than re: blocking periods.



Extended Quota Information



QEI1

The quota definition SID must exist.

Not required   Extended information table is not used by DIT

18.title: Additional codes
18.content:
Additional codes


Introduction to additional codes


How additional codes are used


How additional codes work


How additional codes apply


Additional code types data entities


Business rules


Additional codes are used when a 10-digit commodity code is not enough to identify a traded product, for example for trade remedy purposes, most additional codes identify the companies that the trade is coming from.
Introduction to additional codesUsually, the 10-digits of the commodity code hierarchy are sufficient to identify the product being traded.
Sometimes 10-digits are not enough and an extra 4 or 8-characters needed to communicate sufficient information to describe the trade.  These extra digits are known as additional codes.
112233445566778899101011223344HS chapterHS chapterHS headingHS headingHS subheadingHS sub…Managed by the UKManaged by the UKAdditional TARIC codeAdditional TARIC codeManaged by the WCOManaged by the WCOCN subheadingCN sub…TARIC subheadingTARIC…Managed by the UKManaged by the UKViewer does not support full SVG 1.1
Commodity codes are only ever 10-digits. Additional codes are managed separately and could be applied to multiple commodity codes.
How additional codes are usedAdditional codes show:


anti-dumping and anti-subsidy duties – a code that identifies a company that is subject to punitive measures
pharmaceutical products – a code that identifies an imported good has a reduced duty because it is for pharmaceutical use
the route goods take into the UK and how different tariff or regulatory treatment apply
works of art – to identify items stolen, for example from Syria and Iraq as a result of military conflict

Additional codes are made up of 4-digits, which are split into 2 parts:

How additional codes workAdditional codes are made up of a code type and a 3-digit ID (which can also include letters) when joined together form the unique ID of the additional code.
Numeric IDs from 001 to 999 can be reused across multiple additional code type IDs.
For example, the additional code C233 is constructed of a type © and a specific ID (233) – the entire additional code is known as C233.
Numeric IDs are unique only when they are used with a character code.
How additional codes applyAdditional codes can only be applied to particular types of measures. Types 8, A, B and C can only be used with trade remedies.


Additional code types data entities
Business rules
        
          
#


Rule


Notes

Core   additional code type rules







CT1
The additional code type must be unique.



Required     We are providing the opportunity to create new additional   code types, as these will be required to extend with regard to Trade Remedies   when additional code type ‘C’ runs out.


CT2
The Meursing table plan can only be entered if the   additional code type has as application code “Meursing table additional   code type”.



Not required     This field should not be exposed in the interface – value   should always be Null


CT3
The Meursing table plan must exist.



Not required     This field should not be exposed in the interface – value   should always be Null


CT4
The start date must be less than or equal to the end date.



Required     Simple data comparison (if required) – however the   creation pages for all objects such as additional codes will not feature an   end date function – the edit screens will though.


Delete   an additional code type     We can   sidestep all of these by not allowing for the deletion of additional code   types – highly recommended.







CT6
The additional code type cannot be deleted if it is   related with a non-Meursing additional code.



Not Required     We should not permit deletion of additional code types


CT7
The additional code type cannot be deleted if it is   related with a Meursing Table plan.



Not Required     We should not permit deletion of additional code types –   The Meursing plan is 99% certain to become a thing of the past in any case.


CT9
The additional code type cannot be deleted if it is   related with an Export refund code.



Not Required     We should not permit deletion of additional code types –   ERNs are also dead objects


CT10
The additional code type cannot be deleted if it is   related with a measure type.



Not Required     We should not permit deletion of additional code types


CT11
The additional code type cannot be deleted if it is   related with an Export Refund for Processed Agricultural Goods additional   code.



Not Required     We should not permit deletion of additional code types –   ERNs are also dead objects



Rule



Notes


ACN1
The combination of additional code type + additional code   + start date must be unique.



Required     Additional codes are uniquely identified by their   additional code type and additional code fields, which in conjunction, at any   given time are unique. However code combinations can be reused over time,   hence the use of the additional code SID field – an internal identifier to   identify specific instances of these combinations, as they may be reused.   Therefore this must be checked.     In actual fact, the rule is written incorrectly here.   There must be no overlap in time between two codes both identified with the   same additional code type and additional code – you need to check for this   overlap, which is not permitted, rather than just the coincidence of the   validity start date.


ACN2
The referenced additional code type must exist and have as   application code “non- Meursing” or “Export Refund for   Processed Agricultural Goods”.



Required     See earlier in this document for more info on   additional code type application codes. The most crucial piece is to ensure   that the additional code type actually exists.


ACN3
The start date of the additional code must be less than or   equal to the end date.



Required     Simple date comparison, which will be impacted when an   additional code is being edited – there is no option to enter an end date on   creation.


ACN4
The validity period of the additional code must not   overlap any other additional code with the same additional code type +   additional code + start date.



Required (but see ACN1)     This is a cack-handed way of explaining ACN1 – the two   can be delivered in conjunction by using the business rule explained against   ACN1 above


ACN12
When the additional code is used to represent an   additional code line table component then the validity period of the   additional code must span the validity period of the component.



Not required     Used for complex Meursing code applications – we are   expecting to not use Meursing codes / table.


ACN13
When an additional code is used in an additional code   nomenclature measure then the validity period of the additional code must   span the validity period of the measure.



Required     This will be most frequently used in Trade Remedies   (anti-dumping and anti-subsidy measures). As always, this is best countered   by not putting an end date on an additional code, but should be checked   anyway.


ACN17
The validity period of the additional code type must span   the validity period of the additional code.



Required     As above, we should simply never end-date additional   codes, but strictly–speaking, this is required.



Rule



Notes


Footnote   association







ACN6

The footnotes that are referenced must exist.

Not required     There is no means of publicly viewing footnotes associated   with additional codes, therefore the feature is redundant



ACN7

The start date of the footnote association must be less   than or equal to the end date of the footnote association.

Not required     There is no means of publicly viewing footnotes associated   with additional codes, therefore the feature is redundant



ACN8

The period of the association with a footnote must be   within (inclusive) the validity period of the additional code.

Not required     There is no means of publicly viewing footnotes associated   with additional codes, therefore the feature is redundant



ACN9

The period of the association with a footnote must be   within (inclusive) the validity period of the footnote.

Not required     There is no means of publicly viewing footnotes associated   with additional codes, therefore the feature is redundant



ACN10

When the same footnote is associated more than once with   the same additional code then there may be no overlap in their association   periods.

Not required     There is no means of publicly viewing footnotes associated   with additional codes, therefore the feature is redundant



ACN11

The referenced footnote must have a footnote type with   application type = "non-Meursing additional code footnotes”.

Not required     There is no means of publicly viewing footnotes associated   with additional codes, therefore the feature is redundant



Additional   code description and description periods







ACN5

At least one description is mandatory. The start date of   the first description period must be equal to the start date of the   additional code. No two associated description periods may have the same   start date. The start date must be less than or equal to the end date of the   additional code.

Required    On creating the additional code in the first instance, the first   description must commence on the same start date as the additional code. On   editing the description, this will need to be checked. We must not allow   users to delete the first applicable description.



Delete   an additional code







ACN14

An additional code cannot be deleted if it is used in an   additional code nomenclature measure.

Required     The new project should consider not allowing additional   codes to be deleted – there will scarcely be a requirement to do so.



ACN15

An additional code cannot be deleted if it is used in an   additional code line table component.

Not Required     This refers specifically to Meursing code additional codes   – we will not be providing the capability to manage this relationship, but   most importantly, as above: we should consider not allowing additional codes   to be deleted.

19.title: Quota blocking
19.content:
Quota blocking


Why are quotas blocked?


Quota blocking reasons


Simplified quotas data model (as applies to blocking periods)


Quota blocking data object in detail


A blocking period must fit within a definition period


Managing blocking periods on TAP


Key user needs


Key business rules






Unlike suspensions, blocks don’t prevent declarations being made against a quota, instead they temporarily block quota allocations from being taken, so demand for a quota can be assessed. Quota blocking periods are applicable only to First Come First Serve quotas.
Please read the discussion on blocking quotas before reading this - the introduction to quotas is useful and the concepts are very similar.

Why are quotas blocked?

Quota blocks are placed on quotas for a limited period of time to prevent allocations from being taken.
Unlike suspensions, which effectively invalidate a quota (as if it does not exist and is suspended in law), all a blocking period does is to prevent allocations from being made: it does not prevent declarations from being made against a quota: it just postpones any allocation decision.
A quota blocking period usually coincides with the start of a definition period, though not always; for instance, a common blocking reason is to protect the re-opening of a quota after significant returns
This effect of a quota blocking period is to give HMRC an opportunity to assess the demand for a quota and potentially give an opportunity for them to make subjective decisions on allocations, e.g. to prevent a single large business from using up an entire allocation before smaller players have got their act together.
277 of the 455 blocking periods created in 2019 coincided with the start of definition period.
In these cases, it is most likely that the block will last c. 2 or 3 weeks


Quota blocking reasonsUnlike with suspensions, where the Tariff Manager can only enter descriptive text to describe a suspension period, blocking periods include a field which describe the reason for the blocking period.

        
          

ID

Reason

Count


1

Block   the allocations for a quota due to a late publication.

1637


2

Block   the allocations for a quota after its reopening due to a volume increase.

82


3

Block   the allocations for a quota after its reopening due to the reception of quota   return requests.

1665


4

Block   the allocations for a quota due to the modification of the validity period   after receiving quota return requests.

7


5

Block   the allocations for a quota on request of a MSA.

3


6

Block   the allocations for a quota due to an end-user decision.

69


7

Block   the allocations for a quota due to an exceptional condition.

178


8

Block   the allocations for a quota after its reopening due to a balance transfer.

8

        
      Options 1 and 3 are the most common – option 1 actually seems more by design that just accidental late publication
Logical model of a quota blocking period

A quota starts on Jan 1st and runs throughout the year
The decision is taken to place a block on the quota for the first 15 days, to allow HMRC to make an assessment on potential usage of the quota, by taking allocation requests, but not actually allocating / decrementing the opening balance
This gives smaller traders and new entrants an opportunity to take advantage of the reduced rate
Simplified quotas data model (as applies to blocking periods)
Quota blocking data object in detailAs with suspension periods, the quota blocking object is not one of the more complex objects in the database: there are few fields, in fact there are only three that you need to actively define.


        
          

Field

Description


quota_blocking_period_sid

Unique   identifier, automatically generated by the application when a new suspension   period is created – you do not create this yourself


quota_definition_sid

The   quota definition to which the suspension is to be attached – you do not need   to enter the ID of the definition: you select it from a list (as will be   demonstrated)


blocking_start_date

The   start date of the suspension blocking period – i.e. 00:00 at the start of the   chosen day


blocking_end_date

The   end date of the suspension blocking period – i.e. 00:00 at the end of the   chosen day


blocking_periods_type

One   of the 8 options noted previously – largely options 1 or 3


description

An   optional field, up to 500 characters in length, that helps to define the   blocking period and the reasons for it.

        
      
A blocking period must fit within a definition periodThe critical point is that a quota blocking period is defined against a quota definition period: the blocking period MUST NOT straddle the boundary of the definition – in the rare occasion you need to straddle a boundary, create 2 blocking periods

Managing blocking periods on TAP[Not yet sure if this will go in a different section so I have omitted this from this page for now - This section is covered in pages 11-19 in the powerpoint]
