Condition code B means “Presentation of a certificate/licence/document” and is common to both conditions.
There is no trigger price (hence 4 * null fields across both conditions).
Action codes are complementary (27 and 7) – the 27 is the positive and the 7 is the negative.
The certificate required to effect the positive action is Y085

AND / OR logic for condition codes

Conditions are grouped together according to their condition code.
Within that group, the individual conditions are grouped together in an OR relationship, for example, in the conditions associated with the B condition code below, only one of the three noted goods needs to be provided, however it must be provided alongside one of the other conditions from block E being met (provision of a document or the weight of the imported good being below 2kg).
In this way, an additional tier is added to the logical condition model via the condition code grouping.



Volumes of conditions

Do not underestimate the complexity of measure conditions – there are up to 26 conditions on measures, as per the example here on commodity code 0308110000 (Aquatic invertebrates other than crustaceans and molluscs, live, fresh, chilled, frozen, dried, salted or in brine; smoked aquatic invertebrates other than crustaceans and molluscs, whether or not cooked before or during the smoking process; flours, meals and pellets of aquatic invertebrates other than crustaceans and molluscs, fit for human consumption)against the EU (measure_sid 3566626)
In this case, the conditions are aligned against 2 condition codes:


within condition code B and E respectively, any of the positive conditions will result in an acceptance of the trade.
at least one condition needs to be fulfilled within each of the two condition code groups.

The intellectual knowledge of certification is a huge challenge in DIT, Defra and HMG as a whole - over the implementation period, significant effort in DIT and Defra should be expended in looking to understand certification.


Detailed overview of condition codesCondition code A


This condition code is used to modify the circumstances of an anti-dumping or anti-subsidy duty depending on the conditions stated.
There are three scenarios in which this condition code is used, two of which have 2 related (and opposite action codes)


Scenario 1 – apply conditional duties depending on supply of document
Scenario 2 – determine if the trade can go ahead
Scenario 3 - determining applicability of exemption/reduction of the anti-dumping duty


Scenario 1 – apply conditional duties depending on supply of document


This is by far the most common application of conditional duties for trade remedy-related measures
The applicable duty can be conditional on the supply of a document: if the document is supplied then the duty is reduced
This scenario is executed by:


setting multiple (usually two) measure conditions with condition code A
then assigning action code 01, which states ”Apply the amount of the action”
and to each condition then assigning an applicable duty

The documents used in the EU, presumably to be followed in the UK are as follows:


D005 - Commercial invoice within the framework of undertakings
D008 - Invoice with a signed declaration
D017 - Commercial invoice within the framework of undertakings and Export Undertaking Certificate
D018 - Invoice for transactions which are not exempted from countervailing/anti-dumping duties


Scenario 2 – determine if the trade can go ahead at all


Features a pair of action codes which are always supplied together and are opposites of each other


08 - Declared subheading not allowed
The trade will be rejected in CDS
This is always associated with no document being specified, therefore not presented with the trade
28 - Declared subheading allowed
This is always associated with a document being specified, therefore presented with the trade and hence, the trade being permitted

There is only one certificate that has been used in conjunction with this condition code / action code permutation


D020 - Commercial invoice and mill certificate as defined in Regulation 2015/1953

This scenario is not currently in use, but it has been used in the past

Scenario 3 – determining applicability of exemption/reduction of the anti-dumping duty


As with scenario 2, this features a pair of conditions with complementing action codes that are always found together
Though not completely defunct, this is used only three times in current measures by the EU
The two action codes are:


34 - Apply exemption/reduction of the anti-dumping duty
14 - The exemption/reduction of the anti-dumping duty is not applicable

This basically means that the antidumping duty will be waived entirely or reduced according to the legislation. There are no conditional duties set however, therefore it is not 100% clear where the duty calculation will get its raw data from
The conditions should be applied in the sequence 34 then 14, i.e. positive followed by negative
There is only one current certificate in use that is used with this condition code / action code combination


D008 - Invoice with a signed declaration




Conditions B, C and H are identical in meaning
C and H are used when multiple condition sets using the same mechanic need to be applied to the same measure.

Condition codes B, C & H


Codes B, C and H require a certificate or other document to be presented in order for the requirement to be fulfilled.
Condition codes C & H are identical to condition code B, and there is no overt reason as to why C / H might be used instead of B – they are however sometimes used alongside code B.
Commodity code 8418690091 provides the answer as to why there are two types of condition that are ostensibly identical, i.e. there is a desire to apply multiple conditions sets to the same measure (in this case Import control of fluorinated greenhouse gases).
If just B had been used, it would not have been possible to apply the AND logic of the two condition groups.
H is used only 41 times (Jan 2020); C is used c. 5,000 times whereas B is vastly more prevalent (c. 24,000 occurrences).


Condition code E


This condition code is a combination of a quantitative restriction plus a documentation requirement, i.e. a trade will be allowed provided the volume of goods is lower than the defined threshold weight (or other unit), or a document is provided that permits the trade in a larger volume of goods.
The criteria that define these two conditions are set in the measure condition data.


Condition code I


These condition codes are currently used uniquely with measure types 751 and 755 (import and export control of waste)
They are functionally identical to condition code E (see above).
Type I is only ever used in conjunction with type E to present a send condition set of the same type, never on its own


Condition code F


These conditions allow duties to be charged against imported goods subject to Trade Remedies (Anti dumping or anti subsidy duties) that are dependent upon the unit price of the import.
This is significantly less commonly used than condition code A, which is also used to apply conditional logic to the trade of a good subject to an AD / AS duty, but remains an option for the TRA: there are 119 such conditions against 17,000 + of type A.
In the example below on measure 3571830 on commodity 2933610000 (melamine), there are two F-type conditions, which are dependent on the import price: the duties are set accordingly.
What these conditions say is:


if the goods is imported at a price of higher than €1153 per tonne, then apply zero additional punitive duty (condition 1)
BUT if the import of the good is at a lower price, apply the difference between the import price and the punitive duty

This essentially sets a minimum import 


Condition code L


This is currently used only 30 times and is always applied to measures of type 652 - Additional duty based on cif price
This measure type is used in managing a complex agricultural duty called “Representative prices for chicken”, which in the EU tariff is applied to certain poultry products that are being traded from Argentina, Brazil, Chile and Thailand – the most aggressive of chicken traders.
The UK is not going to be taking on this policy, unless plans change between now and the end of 2020.
The policy is far too complex to describe here, but is described in detail in the general training manual.

Condition code M


Condition code M is used in two circumstances:


The first circumstance is the in managing EU supplied credibility checks of type:
430 Control of particulars of the declaration (suspicious value/net weight or value/supplementary unit)
483 Declaration of subheading submitted to restrictions (value)

A credibility check is a mechanism that is employed in a border system to attempt to reduce errors in declarations by enforcing a check on (for example) the weight versus item count ratio of a declaration.
430 and 483 are measures (along with 431) that are used by the EU to ensure that discrepancies are avoided.
The EU provides these across the whole of the EU because they are trying to ensure consistency and reduce errors (that they have to fix for all 28 member states).
After EU Exit, the UK will provide its own credibility checks – the EU’s measures will be terminated
In reality, the EU’s credibility checks are a small subset of the overall number of checks that are carried out. CHIEF and CDS are replete with many UK-specific credibility checks as well. In the future, these will all be managed by HMRC, not by DIT MTPO, therefore are out of scope for DIT (albeit there is nothing to prevent TAP from creating these).
The second circumstance will continue after EU Exit, as it deals with Trade Remedies. The existing conditions of this type are against measure type ID 552 Definitive anti-dumping duty, but there is no reason why this would not also be assigned to measure types 551, 553 and 554.
This follows a similar pattern to other threshold-based commodities previously noted
There are currently (Jan 2020) 84 instances of condition code M.
In the examples below, there are two conditions which behave more or less the same as condition type F, where the applicable punitive duty is dependent the declared price [F depends on net free at frontier price before duty].


Condition code Q


Condition type Q is used in all cases where a measure is put in place to represent a licensed quota. And in all cases it refers to the single license Y100 (Special entries on the import licence AGRIM). It is used in measures of type:


122  Non preferential tariff quota
123  Non preferential tariff quota under end-use
142  Tariff preference
143  Preferential tariff quota

It is only used for licensed quotas; it is never used for FCFS quotas.


Condition code R


As per scenario 1 for condition code M, this is used to apply conditions to credibility checks to ensure that the weight ‘looks right’ against the number of declared goods. The supplementary unit identifies what additional unit beyond the KGM weight must be supplied by the trader on declaring their import.
Again, as per condition code M, the UK will be abandoning the practise of managing credibility checks in the Taric file after EU Exit.

Condition code U


As per scenario 1 for condition codes M & R, this is used to apply conditions to credibility checks to ensure that the declared value ‘looks right’ against the number of declared goods.
The supplementary unit identifies what additional unit beyond the KGM weight must be supplied by the trader on declaring their import.
As per condition codes M & R, the UK will be abandoning the practise of managing credibility checks in the Taric file after EU Exit.

Condition code V – The Entry price System


The Entry Price System (EPS) is a complex mechanism to apply tiered duties to 31 agricultural products, primarily fruit.
The EPS is described in detail elsewhere, so this page will not go into that much detail, especially as the UK will be abandoning the Entry Price System. It supports growers of (primarily) citrus fruits in Southern Europe: the UK’s less sunny climes do not lend themselves to industrial-scale citriculture.




The screen above is captured from the third country duty for cherry tomatoes – this shows the EPS in action.
The duties that are applicable depend on the import price: the cheaper the import, the more expensive the duty
The purpose of this is to protect domestic growers in s. Europe from influxes of very cheap goods.


In the example above, each row is a price threshold: if the import price falls below a given threshold, then the duty from the row below is charged.
The data for EPS-related measures is as per the example to the below – just one row (marquee below).

This is, as its name suggests a catch all that can be used to manage effectively any condition not specifically covered by the other condition codes. In practice, this seems to have been used in the past by the EU for managing certificates, much in the vein of conditions with code B, C or H. But the real reason for using this is for non-specific conditions that are not associated with a specific document.
These miscellaneous conditions are linked to in much the same way that certificates are referenced, using the certificate type code and certificate code fields. Here are a few examples of conditions that are referenced by condition code Y. None of these are documents per se: they reference properties of goods or activities undertaken by traders outside of the core declaration flow.
For example:
* Y019  Request for preferential treatment for Iceland
* Y021  Request for EEA preferential treatment
* Y034  Derogation from export prohibition by virtue of Article 4.1 of Council Regulation (EU) 2017/1509
* Y037  Goods exempted from the prohibition – biathlon equipment
None of the conditions linked to via the condition code ‘Y’ utilise the price threshold fields.
Condition code Z

Condition code Z is used solely on national P & R measures currently, though it is by no means a stipulation that this has to be so. Indeed, all the national P & R will become homogenised with the measures inherited from the EU after EU Exit – though the management of measures to support the NI Protocol may influence the specific approach.
These are the measure types where Z is used:


ATT   Attestation Document (horticulture and potatoes)
CEX   DCMS Open General Export Licence
COE   Home Office Controlled Drugs (export)
COI   HMI Conformity Certificate (fruit and veg) issued in UK
EQC   Certificate of Conformity
HOP   Home Office pre-cursor chemical authorisation
PRE   Home Office Pre-cursor chemicals
PRT   Home Office Controlled Drugs (import)

There is no reason why this condition code should be used in preference to B, C or H. Indeed there are occasions where the Z type is used, but only one positive condition is included, which seems to make the condition type pretty redundant (e.g. with EQC measures).
The advice to tariff managers would be to always use condition code B, then C then H before resorting to Z.
Key business processing rules
        
          
#
Rule
Notes

ME53
The referenced measure condition must exist.
Required   This applies when assigning conditions components to   conditions A measure obvs has to be in existence too for a measure condition   to be generated in the first place.

ME54
The validity period of the referenced measure condition   must span the validity period of the measure.
Not required - disregard   As far as we can see, this is an erroneous business rule:   the measure condition table does not have a start and end date field. The   condition adopts the start and end dates of the parent measure. Similarly,   there are no start and end dates associated with a measure condition   component (or for that matter a measure component). They all adopt the date   constraints of the parent measure.

ME55
A measure condition refers to a measure condition or to a condition   + certificate or to a condition + amount specifications.
Disregard   This has been written so vaguely that there are no rules   to be gleaned from it

ME56
The referenced certificate must exist.
Required   A certificate must exist before being assigned to a   condition – match must be made on the 2 clustered primary key fields of   certificate type code and certificate code

ME57
The validity period of the referenced certificate must   span the validity period of the measure.
Required   The optimal way for us to handle this is to NEVER expire   certificates – there is literally no need. However the validity start dates   and end dates of the measure and the certificate need to be checked. See note   at the foot of this document as to how null end dates have been dealt with in   terms of comparing extents – to reduce code

ME58
The same certificate can only be referenced once by the   same measure and the same condition type.
Required   There should never be a requirement to apply a certificate   more than once, but it needs to be checked. Again – use the 2 pronged cluster   primary key.

ME59
The referenced action code must exist.
Debatable   The measure action table should remain fixed – by making   any modifications to this table, we are creating a lot of work for downstream   systems which need to be adjusted to cater for the change (CDS, Gems,   Caesar).

ME60
The referenced monetary unit must exist.
Required    Conditions are put in place to respond either to the   provision of some sort of document / license or to respond to a minimum   threshold import price – if the latter then there is a requirement to specify   a valid monetary unit, which is always likely to be GBP.

ME61
The validity period of the referenced monetary unit must   span the validity period of the measure.
Required - debatable   The unit will always be GBP or EUR – all we need to do is   to ensure that the units are not end-dated

ME61
The validity period of the referenced monetary unit must   span the validity period of the measure.
Required - debatable   The unit will always be GBP or EUR – all we need to do   is to ensure that the units are not end-dated

ME62
The combination measurement unit + measurement unit   qualifier must exist.
Required   The relationship between a measurement_unit and any   qualifer that can be used against that measurement unit is defined in the   table “measurements” – this needs to be observed fully or CDS will generate   an error. Measurements have start and end dates against them, and these also   need to be observed.

ME63
The validity period of the measurement unit must span the   validity period of the measure.
Required   Measurement units have start dates end dates – we need   to observe these start and end dates in the creation of measures. We are not   offering a tool to manage measurement units in the first instance.

ME64
The validity period of the measurement unit qualifier must   span the validity period of the measure.
Required   Measurement unit qualifiers have start dates end dates   – we need to observe these start and end dates in the creation of measures.   We are not offering a tool to manage qualifiers in the first instance.

ME105
The referenced duty expression must exist.
Required   There is a specified list of duty expressions that can   be used in TAP / CDS. We must not use any duty expressions that are not   valid.

ME106
The VP of the duty expression must span the VP of the   measure.
Required   There are a number of duty expressions that are no   longer valid – they have been end dated (in 1996 and 2016 primarily). We must   not use these.

ME108
The same duty expression can only be used once within   condition components of the same condition of the same measure. (i.e. it can   be re-used in other conditions, no matter what condition type, of the same   measure)
Required   Even if an expression that (in English) reads the same   needs to be used more than once in a measure, we must use a different   expression ID, never the same one twice.

ME109
If the flag ‘amount’ on duty expression is ‘mandatory’   then an amount must be specified. If the flag is set to ‘not permitted’ then   no amount may be entered.
Required   The three possible values for this field on the   duty_expressions table are:   0 - Permitted   1 - Mandatory   2 - Not permitted   These values must be observed – By the way, we should   not allows users to modify the data associated with duty expressions, as the   knock on impact will be too significant.

ME110
If the flag ‘monetary unit’ on duty expression is   ‘mandatory’ then a monetary unit must be specified. If the flag is set to   ‘not permitted’ then no monetary unit may be entered.
Required   The three possible values for this field on the   duty_expressions table are:   0 - Permitted   1 - Mandatory   2 - Not permitted   These values must be observed – As above, we should not   allows users to modify the data associated with duty expressions.

ME111
If the flag ‘measurement unit’ on duty expression is   ‘mandatory’ then a measurement unit must be specified. If the flag is set to   ‘not permitted’ then no measurement unit may be entered.
Required   The three possible values for this field on the   duty_expressions table are:   0 - Permitted   1 - Mandatory   2 - Not permitted   These values must be observed – As above, we should not   allows users to modify the data associated with duty expressions.

25.title: Nomenclature
25.content:
Commodity codes


Concepts and terminology


Commodity codes


HS - Harmonised System


Sections




CN - Combined Nomenclature


TARIC - Tarif Intégré Communautaire / Tarif intégré des Communautés européennes




Product line suffixes


Indents


In practice


Chapters 98 and 99




Declarability and measure assignment


Jams and jellies are very complex


Smashing preconceptions on hierarchical inheritance




Changes to commodity codes


New commodities - examples


Do not underestimate WCO changes




Origins


Successors


Residual codes


Business rules




Commodity codes are 10-digit codes that refer to specific products, traders must put these codes on their declaration forms when importing or exporting goods.
Nomenclature, also known as goods classification, goods nomenclature or commodity code classification, is the name for the full list of products in the UK Tariff.

Concepts and terminology

The UK refers to the full list of products in the UK Tariff as the Goods Classification – this is synonymous with the broad name for the full list of products: goods nomenclature or just nomenclature.
In the EU, this is referred to under multiple names: often the EU refers to the Tariff as the “Combined Nomenclature” (CN), though officially this refers only to the first 8 digits of the code.
Within the broader body, the individual elements referring to specific products are called commodity codes.
There are about 25,000 commodity codes of which about 16,000 are declarable end-lines.

There are three key concepts to understand in this section. All of these have a significant impact on the measures that can be defined and managed by Tariff Managers:


commodity codes
product line suffixes
indents

Commodity codesThese are the 10-digit codes that traders put on their declaration forms when importing or exporting goods.
Commodity codes are often shown with fewer than 10 characters to represent higher levels of the classification hierarchy – in these cases, the missing digits are always zeroes. For example, HS4 code “0102” really represents the 10-digit code “0102000000”. Any spaces or dots added to commodity codes are for presentation purposes only.


G



HS

1

2

3

4

5

6

HS chapter

HS heading

HS
subheading

Managed by WCO




CN

7

8

9

10

CN
subheading

TARIC
subheading

Managed by EU




HS--CN



HS - Harmonised System

The first six digits of the code numbers of the tariff or TARIC have been regulated by the World Customs Organization (WCO) in the form of the HS nomenclature world-wide since 1988.
HS is currently used in 176 countries. A revision takes place regularly, roughly every 5 years (so far, 1996, 2002, 2007, 2012, 2017). Next change anticipated in 2022.

Sections

The Harmonised System is categorised into sections and chapters
The section is a logical grouping that is not reflected in the nomenclature.
Each chapter, which is a subdivision of a section, is fully self-contained within the logical section.
Sections are represented by Roman numerals (1 to 21 / I to XXI)



        
          
Chapter
Description

I
Live   animals; animal products (chapter 1 - 5)

II
Vegetable   products (chapter 6 - 14)

III
Animal   or vegetable fats and oils and their cleavage products; prepared edible fats;   animal or vegetable waxes (chapter 15)

IV
Prepared   foodstuffs; beverages, spirits and vinegar; tobacco and manufactured tobacco   substitutes (chapter 16 - 24)

V
Mineral   products (chapter 25 - 27)

VI
Products   of the chemical or allied industries (chapter 28 - 38)

VII
Plastics   and articles thereof; rubber and articles thereof (chapter 39 - 40)

VIII
Raw   hides and skins, leather, furskins and articles thereof; saddlery and   harness; travel goods, handbags and similar containers; articles of animal   gut (other than silkworm gut) (chapter 41 - 43)

IX
Wood   and articles of wood; wood charcoal; cork and articles of cork; manufactures   of straw, of esparto or of other plaiting materials; basketware and   wickerwork (chapter 44 - 46)

X
Pulp   of wood or of other fibrous cellulosic material; recovered (waste and scrap)   paper or paperboard; paper and paperboard and articles thereof (chapter   (chapter 47 - 49)

XI
Textiles   and textile articles (chapter 50 - 63)

XII
Footwear,   headgear, umbrellas, sun umbrellas, walking-sticks, seat-sticks, whips,   riding-crops and parts thereof; prepared feathers and articles made   therewith; artificial flowers; articles of human hair (chapter 64 - 67)

XIII
Articles   of stone, plaster, cement, asbestos, mica or similar materials; ceramic   products; glass and glassware (chapter 68 - 70)

XIV
Natural   or cultured pearls, precious or semi-precious stones, precious metals, metals   clad with precious metal and articles thereof; imitation jewellery; coins   (chapter 71)

XV
Base   metals and articles of base metal (chapter 72 - 83)

XVI
Machinery   and mechanical appliances; electrical equipment; parts thereof, sound   recorders and reproducers, television image and sound recorders and   reproducers, and parts and accessories of such articles (chapter 84 - 85)

XVII
Vehicles,   aircraft, vessels and associated transport equipment (chapter 86 - 89)

XVIII
Optical,   photographic, cinematographic, measuring, checking, precision, medical or   surgical instruments and apparatus; clocks and watches; musical instruments;   parts and accessories thereof (chapter 90 - 92)

XIX
Arms   and ammunition; parts and accessories thereof (chapter 93)

XX
Miscellaneous   manufactured articles (chapter 94 - 96)

XXI
Works   of art, collectors’ pieces and antiques (chapter 97 - 99)

        
      CN - Combined Nomenclature

The “Combined Nomenclature” specifies the first eight digits of the Tariff. This eight-digit nomenclature can not be changed over a period of one year and applies both in the EU and the Associated States (BG, RO, TR, etc.).

TARIC - Tarif Intégré Communautaire / Tarif intégré des Communautés européennes

Taric, the tariff rate of the European Communities, is the same as the CN in the first eight digits. There is, therefore, a uniform marking for customs purposes and statistics. The Taric is subdivided however by the Taric sub-positions (from the ninth place) more deeply.
As the combined nomenclature is not sufficiently detailed to support the community tariff and commercial legislation, the 8-digit codes can be broken down into 10-digit codes called “TARIC codes”. 
These codes are created at any time, according to the EU’s legislative needs.

Product line suffixesThe product line suffix is a device introduced by the WCO and adopted by the EU and UK to be able to add order and structure to the goods hierarchy. A value of “80” means that the good represents a commodity code that in theory could be declared and exists in legislation.
A value of less than 80 (e.g. “10”, “20”, “30”, etc) means that the commodity code is only present for grouping and structure purposes. Measures can only be attached to codes with a suffix of 80.
IndentsThe tariff originated primarily as a printed document. The indent was used to identify how many centimetres the heading was to be indented on the page. This gives a good indication as to how deep the commodity code is in the hierarchy but unfortunately there are several issues that prevent it from representing the depth exactly.
In practice

The schematic below illustrates a ‘hierarchy’ starting from the very first commodity code in the Tariff (0100 00 00 00) down to the last end-line under the 1st major HS heading branch (0101 90 00 00), i.e. Live horses, asses, mules and hinnies
This shows the commodity codes, split into segments for ease of reading, the product line suffix and the indent, as well as the current description of the commodity code.
The physical indent on the description matches the indent field.
Hence, Horses is a ‘child’ of ‘Live horses, asses, mules and hinnies’ and ‘Pure-bred breeding animals’ is a child of ‘Horses’ – however these relationships are inferred, not explicit.
You will notice that there are two zeroes at the start of the tree – this is a slightly bewildering treatment, but we need to work with it: the HS chapter and the HS heading both use an indent of 0.
Note that in some chapters (e.g. 29) there are three levels of 0-indent headings. This is because there are additional grouping headings in the legislation with Roman numerals and these are represented in the tariff at zero indent and with a suffix of 10.


If one were to try and print out the whole commodity tree (c. 24,500 lines), you would:


select the commodity codes with current validity
sort them by commodity code and then product line suffix
indent them using the indent field

Chapters 98 and 99Chapters 98 and 99 are part of the EU’s special coding system and are not defined by the WCO Harmonised System.
Chapter 98 is for statistical reporting purposes for industrial plant and is never declared directly by traders – no codes in this chapter have measures so it would be impossible to declare on it.
Chapter 99 contains codes for certain specific movements of goods, such as personal effects belonging to a person moving house. Chapter 99 was optional for Member States under the EU customs code and the UK did not legislate for its use, so it is currently not available for declarations but remains in the dataset. It’s also worth noting that chapter 99, despite having extra subheadings like chapter 29, doesn’t have three levels of zero indent.
Declarability and measure assignment

The import declaration requires that the trader enter the most detailed description possible for the good that is being traded, not something vague like ‘Horses’
There are two rules that define whether or not a good is declarable, i.e. whether or not it can be entered onto an import declaration form:
first, a good must have a product line suffix (PLS) of “80”: anything else cannot be traded – these commodity codes are in the database purely as structural fillers
second, a good must be an end-line aka a leaf. i.e. it must not have any children.
In the example below, the declarable commodities are those with a D against them
Although 0101 29 00 00, 01010 00 00 00 and 0101 00 00 00 all have a PLS of “80”, they all have child codes underneath them, therefore cannot be declared.




In the example above (red marquee), it is interesting to note (and this is key in understanding where a product line suffix other than “80” is used), that there are two items with the commodity code 0101 21 00 00.
One has a PLS of 10, the other has a PLS of 80.
This is common and is likely to be a treatment we need to get used to in the UK for future change.

Jams and jellies are very complex


The image above shows the complexity of certain hierarchies.
The indent numbers have been doctored slightly to show the true number of indents, ignoring the double zero noted previously.
There are actually 14 tiers of data in certain points in the hierarchy, as shown here
This is exceptional however
Please also note the apparently inconsistent use of product line suffixes: why has 2007 99 39 00 got a PLS of “80” when it is clearly an intermediate code?
The answer seems to be that the non-80 code is used where there is a need to insert a structural heading with the same commodity code as the subsequent code, presumably due to space restrictions in the hierarchy.

Smashing preconceptions on hierarchical inheritance


This is undoubtedly an unusually complex tree, however it does illustrate well a concept that needs to be understood, to help the Tariff management team to grasp the idea of inheritance, which is critical in measure management.
The 10-digit commodity code is divided into 5 pairs of digits.
While it is alluring to consider that these two digit pairs provide enough information to work out the hierarchy, this is coincidental, though, certainly at the top of the hierarchy, frequently true.

Changes to commodity codesNew commodities - examples
Do not underestimate WCO changes


The graph above shows the peaks and troughs of nomenclature management over the last 10 years
The 2 big peaks are on 1st Jan 2012 and 1st Jan 2017, the to dates in the last 10 years where the WCO has made alterations to their HS6 structures.
Every non-WCO year follows a similar peak / trough structure
Big peak in Jan (annual CN code changes, smaller peak in July (new suspension), ad hoc for the rest of the year
2019 was an outlier, as commodity code changes have taken place throughout the year

Origins

An origin defines the commodity code from which a new commodity code was derived.
When a commodity code is split into two, the ‘origin’ of the two (or more) new commodity codes is the parent commodity code.




In the example above, a successor will have been created for codes 2001 90 70 10 and 2001 90 70 90 of2001 90 70 00.
It is mandatory that at least one origin is created for every new commodity code
However, this data is of zero value to the Tariff Application

Successors

An successor defines the commodity code into which an existing commodity code has been absorbed.
It is not mandatory for a successor code to be created, though they may be created.

Residual codes

The sweet peppers example can also be used to exemplify residual codes.
A residual code is the code usually labelled ’Other’ which is created when a code is split into a specific and remainder part.
In this example 2001 90 70 00 is split into 2 child codes.


The specific code is assigned 10 as the final 2 digits.
The residual code is assigned 90 as the final 2 digits.
If in future more child codes as added to the parent as siblings to 10 and 90, then these are assigned 20, 30, 40 etc as the final 2 digits, while space remains.





If a code is split on the last digit, rather than the last 2 digits, it is usually split into 1 and 9, for example:




There are more than 6,500 residual codes in the database 

Business rulesBusiness rules that affect commodity codes are listed in the system documentation.

26.title: Validity dates
26.content:
Validity dates


Validity dates on descriptions


Validity date of measures




Tariff elements such as measures and measure descriptions have validity dates, which show when those elements are live.

The tariff database implements a version control system that specifies which elements of the tariff are live on the border on a given day. Most elements use a pair of validity dates: the element is live after the validity start date and before the validity end date.
If the validity end date is blank then the element is live indefinitely. Validity dates can be modified after the initial creation of an element, so an element that initially has a blank end date can be updated to subsequently add one.
Start and end validity dates are inclusive – meaning that the element is live from the beginning of the start date to the end of the end date. An element with the same start and end date is therefore live for 1 day.
Validity dates on descriptionsDescription elements have a requirement that there must always be one live description at any time. For this reason, descriptions do not have end dates and only have start dates. The description is live up until the start date of the next description record.
Validity date of measuresThere are four ways in which measures can get end dated:


Where the measure is given an explicit end date on the measure record itself
Where the measure’s generating regulation is a base regulation, and the base regulation is end-dated
Where the measure’s generating regulation is a modification regulation, and the modification regulation is end-dated
Where the measure’s generating regulation is a modification regulation, and the base regulation that it modifies is end-dated

Numbers 2–4 also have to take account of the “effective end date” which if set should be used over any explicit date. The effective end date is set when other types of regulations are used (abrogation, prorogation, etc).
In the UK tariff, we will not be using regulation end dates and will only ever stop measures by adding end dates explicitly.
